case_name: Sohan Lal v. Union of India and Jagan Nath

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 30, 1953, of the Circuit Bench of the Punjab High Court at Delhi in Civil Writ Application No. 314 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 30, 1953, of the Circuit Bench of the Punjab High Court at Delhi in Civil Writ Applic

facts.text: The respondent Jagan Nath filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the Punjab High Court which was allowed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Jagan Nath filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the Punjab High Court which was allowed.

facts.text: The High Court ordered the respondent The Union of India and the appellant Sohan Lal to forthwith restore possession of house No. 35 situated in West Patel Nagar, Delhi to Jagan Nath.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court ordered the respondent The Union of India and the appellant Sohan Lal to forthwith restore possession of house No. 35 situated in West P

facts.text: Jagan Nath is a displaced person and a refugee from Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: Jagan Nath is a displaced person and a refugee from Pakistan.

facts.text: Government of India devised schemes for rehabilitation of refugees, including sale of certain houses constructed by the Government in West Patel Nagar.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of India had devised various schemes for the rehabilitation of refugees. One of these was a scheme for sale of certain houses const

facts.text: Scheme not intended to entertain applications from displaced persons who had already been allotted agricultural land in East Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: It was number intended -under the scheme to entertain applications from displaced persons who had already been allotted agricultural land in East

facts.text: Eligibility for allotment: displaced persons registered before 15th August 1948 and gainfully employed.

anchor.surface_text: According to -he procedure prescribed in order to give effect to the scheme, only those displaced persons, who were registered before the 15th of A

facts.text: Jagan Nath registered as a refugee on December 31, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Jagan Nath had got himself registered as a refugee on December 31, 1947.

facts.text: Jagan Nath deposited Rs. 5,600 as sale price after prima facie eligibility accepted.

anchor.surface_text: He had deposited the sum of Rs. 5,600 as the sale price after his prima facie eligibility had been accepted.

facts.text: Jagan Nath deposited ground rent for the plot.

anchor.surface_text: He had also deposited the ground rent for the plot on which the house had been built,

facts.text: Jagan Nath informed that allotment by drawing lots on February 15, 1952 at 3 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: He was informed that the allotment of a particular house would be decided by drawing lots at site on February 15, 1952, at 3 p.m.

facts.text: House No. 35 fell to Jagan Nath's lot in drawing.

anchor.surface_text: As the result of the drawing of lots, house No. 35, the property in dispute in this appeal, fell to his lot.

facts.text: According to Jagan Nath, on May 10, 1952, Accommodation Officer removed his family and belongings to house No. 35.

anchor.surface_text: According to Jagan Nath, on May 10, 1952, the Accommodation Officer in his absence removed the members of his family along with his entire b

facts.text: Jagan Nath evicted from house on September 27, 1952 by warrant dated September 11, 1952 under s. 25 of Ordinance III of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Jagan Nath, however, was evicted from the house in dispute on September 27, 1952, by virtue of a warrant of eviction dated September 11, 1952, pu

facts.text: Possession of house given to appellant Sohan Lal on October 3, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: After his eviction,possession of the house in dispute was given to the appellant on October 3, 1952.

facts.text: Appellant Sohan Lal applied for allotment on February 27, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, who is also a displaced person, had applied on February 27, 1952, for allotment of a house in West Patel Nagar.

facts.text: Appellant deposited Rs. 5,600 as sale price.

anchor.surface_text: He had made the deposit of Rs. 5,600 as sale price and had apparently complied with all the necessary conditions

facts.text: House No. 35 allotted to appellant on July 31, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: and the house in dispute was allotted to him on July 31, 1952.

facts.text: Appellant in possession since October 3, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has been in possession of the disputed house since October 3, 1952.

facts.text: There was a serious dispute on questions of fact between the parties and whether Jagan Nath had acquired title.

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 30, 1953, of the Circuit Bench of the Punjab High Court at Delhi in Civil Writ Applic
The respondent Jagan Nath filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the Punjab High Court which was allowed.

concepts.interpretation: Writ jurisdiction under Art. 226 not appropriate for resolving disputed questions of fact and title to property, which should be decided in a civil suit.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: . In our opinion, the High Court erred in allowing the application of Jagan Nath filed under Art. 226 of the Constitution and making the order it did.

issues.text: whether in proceedings under Art. 226 of the Constitution such a declaration ought to be made and restoration of the property to Jagan Nath be ordered

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances to be mentioned hereafter, it is a matter for serious consideration whether in proceedings under Art. 226 of the Constitution such a declaration ought to be made and restoration of the property to Jagan Nath be ordered.

issues.text: what rights were acquired by the former [Jagan Nath] in the property upto the stage when the latter [Union of India] informed Jagan Nath that the property would not be allotted to him

anchor.surface_text: As between Jagan Nath and the Union of India it will be necessary to decide what rights were acquired by the former in the property upto the stage when the latter informed Jagan Nath that the property in question could not be allotted to him.

issues.text: whether Jagan Nath was allowed to enter into possession of the property because it was allotted to him or under a misapprehension as the Union of India was misled by the contents of his application

anchor.surface_text: Another question for decision will be whether Jagan Nath was allowed to enter into possession of the property because it was allotted to him or under a misapprehension as the Union of India was misled by the contents of his application.

issues.text: Did the appellant thereby acquire a legal right to hold the property as against Jagan Nath

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was accordingly given possession of the property after Jagan Naths eviction. The appelant had complied with all the conditions imposed by the Union of India and a letter of allotment was actually issued to him and he entered into possession of the property in dispute under the authority of the Union of India. Did the appellant thereby acquire a legal right to hold the property as against Jagan Nath?

issues.text: Whether having regard to the circumstances of the case, the High Court erred in making the order it did which purported to be in the nature of a writ of mandamus where there was serious dispute on questions of fact and title

anchor.surface_text: The appellants main contention has been that, having regard to the circumstances of the case, the High Court erred in making the order it did which presumably purported to be in the nature of a writ of mandamus. There was a serious dispute on questions of fact between the parties and also whether Jagan Nath had acquired in law any title to the property in dispute. Proceedings by way of a writ were not appropriate in a case where the decision of the Court would amount to a decree declaring Jagan Naths title and ordering restoration of possession.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Serious disputes on facts and title require adjudication in civil court, not writ proceedings under Art.226; alternative remedy available.

holdings.text: The eviction of Jagan Nath was in contravention of the express provisions of s. 3 of the Public Premises Eviction Act. His eviction, therefore, was illegal.

holdings.text: A writ of mandamus could issue to or an order in the nature of mandamus could be made against the Union of India to restore possession of the property to Jagan Nath if the property was still in the possession of the Union of India.

holdings.text: We cannot see why in principle there should be a distinction made between such a case and the case of a person, who has, apparently, entered into bona fide possession of a property without knowledge that any person had been illegally evicted therefrom.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot see why in principle there should be a distinction made between such a case and the case of a person, who has, apparently, entered into bona fide possession of a property without knowledge that any person had been illegally evicted therefrom.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy to quo warranto: title to de facto possession tried in specific proceedings, not mandamus.

precedents.cited_proposition: mandamus will not lie against a person in de facto possession of an office unless the election is merely colourable; title must be tried by quo warranto
precedents.cited_holding: it is an inflexible rule of law that where a person has been de facto elected to a corporate office, and has accepted and acted in the office, the validity of the election and the title to the office can only be tried by proceeding on a quo warranto information. A mandamus will number lie unless the election can be shown to be merely companyourable.
